The Act may be cited as the "Belarus Democracy Act of 2002". Congress finds that the United States supports democracy, human rights, and the rule of law in Belarus. The US has a vital interest in Belarus' independence and integration into the European community of democracies. The last free and fair parliamentary election in Belarus was in 1995, after which the authoritarian regime of Aleksandr Lukashenka seized power. In November 1996, Belarusian President Aleksandr Lukashenka orchestrated an illegal referendum to impose a new constitution, abolish the parliament, and extend his term. Democratic forces challenged his actions in May 1999 with alternative elections, leading to repression. Peaceful demonstrations against Lukashenka's regime resulted in beatings, arrests, and incarcerations of activists. (7) Victor Gonchar, Anatoly Krasovsky, Yuri Zakharenka, and Dmitry Zavadsky, known for their democratic leadership and critical journalism, have disappeared and are believed dead. Former Belarus officials have accused top Lukashenka regime members of involvement. The regime systematically suppresses independent media, freedom of speech, and religious groups. The US, EU, and North are involved. The United States, the European Union, NATO Parliamentary Assembly, and OSCE Parliamentary Assembly do not recognize the National Assembly. The parliamentary elections of October 15, 2000, were deemed illegitimate and non-democratic by the OSCE. The presidential election of September 9, 2001, was considered fundamentally unfair and failed to meet democratic election standards set by the OSCE. The Lukashenka regime in Belarus has been accused of significant misconduct, including harassment, arrest, and imprisonment of opposition members, denial of fair media access to opposition candidates, seizure of property from independent organizations, non-transparent voting procedures, and intimidation of activists and media. Assistance to promote democracy and civil society in Belarus. Assistance under this section is available to help the people of Belarus regain their freedom, support free and fair elections, and strengthen democratic institutions. The President is authorized to provide assistance primarily to indigenous Belarusian groups committed to these purposes. Assistance under this section is available to help indigenous Belarusian groups support democratic processes, including election observation, political party development, media support, and professional training programs for democratic leaders. Training programs for leaders and members of democratic forces in skill areas essential for civil society development, along with other activities consistent with the purposes of this Act. Authorization of appropriations up to $40,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 and 2004, with funds available until expended. SEC. 4. RADIO BROADCASTING TO BELARUS. The purpose of this section is to authorize increased support for US and surrogate radio broadcasting to Belarus to facilitate information dissemination. $5,000,000 is authorized annually for Voice of America and RFE/RL, Incorporated for radio broadcasting in Belarusian languages. The Secretary of State must report on how funds will be used for AM and FM broadcasting within 120 days of enactment. The purpose of section 3(d) is to provide AM and FM broadcasting in Belarus for independent and uncensored programming. SEC. 5. SANCTIONS AGAINST THE GOVERNMENT OF BELARUS. Sanctions against Belarus will continue until the government meets specific conditions, including releasing jailed individuals, dropping politically motivated charges against opposition figures, and providing a full account of disappearances of opposition leaders and journalists. The US Congress calls for the prosecution of those responsible for disappearances in Belarus, an end to harassment of media and opposition groups, and free and fair elections. It also recommends denying entry to the US for Belarusian officials and their family members. The US Congress calls for prosecution of those responsible for disappearances in Belarus, an end to harassment of media and opposition groups, and free and fair elections. Prohibition on strategic exports to Belarus includes restrictions on exporting computers, software, and technology for use by the Government of Belarus or its military, police, prison system, or national security agencies. Exceptions are made for goods or technology for democracy-building or humanitarian purposes. The US Congress prohibits loans and investments from US agencies to the Government of Belarus, except for humanitarian goods and agricultural or medical products. Additionally, funds from the Trade and Development Agency cannot be used for activities in Belarus. The US Congress prohibits loans and investments from US agencies to Belarus, except for humanitarian goods and agricultural or medical products. Congress finds that Belarus has failed to respect worker rights and approves the denial of duty-free tariff treatment to Belarus. The President will continue to deny duty-free treatment for Belarusian articles. Congress also expresses the sense that sanctions should apply to Belarus for multilateral financial assistance. The President may waive sanctions on Belarus if it is in the national interests of the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury should oppose financial assistance to Belarus, except for humanitarian loans and aid. SEC. 6. MULTILATERAL COOPERATION

Congress urges the President to work with European countries on a multilateral strategy for Belarus. This includes encouraging other countries to take similar measures as outlined in this Act.

SEC. 7. REPORT. The President must report annually on weapons sales from Belarus to countries supporting terrorism, detailing the weapons involved. The President must report annually on weapons sales from Belarus to countries supporting terrorism, detailing the goods, services, credits, or other consideration received in exchange for weapons or weapons-related technologies, as well as the personal assets and wealth of Belarusian government leaders. Reports may be unclassified with a classified annex. SEC. 8. DECLARATION OF POLICY. Congress expresses support for democracy, rule of law, and sovereignty in Belarus, as well as integration into the European community. They are concerned about disappearances of individuals and call for an end to persecution of political opponents by the Lukashenka regime. They also urge an end to violations of OSCE standards. The OSCE calls on Russia to support democratic development in Belarus and for Belarus to resolve its political crisis through free and fair elections, respecting human rights and allowing opposition access to state media. The democratic opposition in Belarus is commended for their commitment to freedom, courage in facing repression, and the emergence of a pluralist civil society, laying the foundation for democratic political structures. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. "OSCE" stands for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. The term "senior leadership of the Government of Belarus" includes high-ranking officials involved in suppressing freedom in Belarus.
